attributes.title: Ella Campbell
attributes.description: In this study I will be testing to see if alcohol and non alcohol social media postings effect ones drinking behaviors

attributes.title: Does Inflated Sense of Responsibility Increase Maximizing Behavior?
attributes.description: In this study, we are testing whether a sense of inflated responsibility causes people to maximize or put a high level of effort to achieve optimal outcomes, when they are making decisions. A sense of inflated responsibility involves feeling as if one plays a pivotal role in both causing and preventing the negative outcomes of one’s decisions. In this study, a cover story about formulating a music therapy for preventing post-traumatic stress disorder in a population was presented to all participants; in other words, this music selection task is not going to provide input into the development of a novel intervention for PTSD. Participants were assigned randomly to either an inflated responsibility or a non-inflated responsibility condition. Participants in the inflated responsibility condition were led to believe that their selections of music videos would have crucial influence on developing a new intervention for post-traumatic stress disorder. Participants in the non-inflated responsibility condition were told that their decisions would have no or only minimal impact on the intervention. We are testing whether participants who experienced an inflated sense of responsibility tried to maximize when selecting music for the therapy, meaning that they put more effort into the decision in order to make sure they attained the best possible outcome with their choices of songs.

q2.value: Participants who were led to feel an inflated sense of responsibility will be more likely to maximize in the music selection task; they will also be more likely to attempt to avoid future regret.  In other words, there would be significant differences between all three conditions, with the manipulation check, maximizing, and avoiding regret being highest in the high responsibility, lower in the less responsibility, and lowest in the no responsibility conditions.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subject design with 1 factor (level of responsibility) and 3 levels (high: 50 people, medium: 1000 people, low: pilot study)

q7.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the three conditions. The randomization is powered by Qualtrics randomization.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through online research platform, Prolific. Participants will be paid at the rate of $9.25 per hour depending on how long they spend on participating the project. Participants will be at least 18 years old.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 300 participants.

q12.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .85 power to detect a small effect size of .20 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q13.value: All data collection will end before the last week of April 2020 due to time constraint.

question.value: We will manipulate participants' sense of responsibility of how pivotal their music selection is to the final result of music therapy and the target population's wellbeing. The three levels of this categorical variable are: high responsibility: they will be told that they are one of the 50 people selected to provide critical input; low responsibility: they will be told that they are one of the 1000 people selected to provide somewhat important input; no responsibility: they will be told that their input will not impact the target population.

The dependent variables will be maximizing, regret avoidance/anticipated regret, and decision difficulty. Their measures are included in the attached file "Measures-Prolific". Note that all items are answered in a 9-point Likert scale. 1 = completely disagree, 9 = completely agree.
Please see file "Measures-Prolific" for specific combinations of items into indices.
All data analyses will be performed with SPSS 25. We will use one-way ANOVA for manipulation check and the dependent measures.

q18.value: High inflated responsibility condition will be coded as 1, low inflated responsibility condition will be coded as 2, no responsibility condition will be coded as 3.

q19.value: We will use F, p-value, and two-tailed test for the analyses.

In other words, there would be significant differences between all three conditions, with the manipulation check, maximizing, and avoiding regret being highest in the high responsibility, lower in the less responsibility, and lowest in the no responsibility conditions.

attributes.title: Shea Final Project
attributes.description: The study of bias against women is important for the development of equality for women in today's world. The inequality between the sexes is  prevalent everyday. Although progress has been made in today's society to give equal opportunity to all, there remains an underlying bias. Women are judged by the way they look and how attractive they are perceived. This affects the way women are treated and the opportunities people who hold these biases provide them.  In this paper we examine whether there is a correlation between the approachability and attractiveness of a person and the likeliness of a possible bias. The purpose for this study is to see if there is a relationship between attractiveness and approachability. This study is important to help understand the extent of the bias that females face due to the superficial qualities of physical attractiveness on which they are often judged. I believe that there will be significant interaction between the higher the approachability score the higher the attractiveness score. This effect will be stronger in male participants than in female participants.

q2.value: There will be an interaction that the higher the scores for approachability the higher attractiveness scores. This effect will be stronger for male participants than female.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: Dynamic modelling research in Africa
attributes.description: To map the research outputs on dynamic epidemiological modelling of infectious diseases in Africa. This will help to identify the geographic areas with substantial levels of research activities, research themes that are already well explored, areas with gaps and research output trends

q2.value: Dynamic epidemiological models have increasingly gained prominence as tools for understanding the transmission of diseases. Mapping the research outputs will help to identify  levels of research activities, disease modelling themes that are already well explored, areas with gaps and research output trends

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q5.value: This is a scoping review. The data screening involves blinding

question.value: This is a scoping review

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: Preliminary literature search has been done with the use of various databases and search strings.

question.value:
We will check through the titles and abstract and will download identified potential articles. We will then go through the full text . 


Inclusion criteria
•	Primary studies that were conducted with the authors having an African affiliation.
•	Studies that were published in peer-reviewed journals.
Exclusion criteria
•	Review articles
•	Studies that do not focus on applied epidemiological modelling
•	Cost-effectiveness models that do not have an underlying mechanistic model
•	Statistical analyses that do not have an underlying mechanistic model
•	Theoretical modelling exercises that do not link to public health applications.
•	Studies that do not include authors with an African institutional affiliation  
•	Articles published in languages other than English.

q11.value: This depends on what we are able to identify as eligible publications

attributes.title: The Beneficial Effects of Exercise Intervention for Mental Health:  An fMRI Activation Likelihood Estimation Meta-Analysis
attributes.description:
Abstract
Purpose: To first investigate the effects of exercise interventions on mental health through coordinate-based meta-analysis across neuroimaging studies, exploring relevant activated brain regions and interplay among them.
Methods: Literature search was conducted from an inception to March 2020, through four electronic databases (Pubmed, Web of Science, PsychInfo, and Embase).  After screening, a quantitative Activation Likelihood Estimation meta-analysis was performed in 15 studies (19 experiments, 189 foci) with 593 participants to evaluate the contrast pre- versus post- exercise effects on mental health. Additionally, subgroup analyses for memory, executive function, intervention term and age group were carried on as well.
Results: Following the physical exercising intervention, the activation of the left cerebellar tonsil, the right precuneus and the right inferior frontal gyrus were increased while the activation of the right red nucleus, the right caudate head, the left precuneus and the right declive were decreased. Besides, primary activation in precuneus and red nucleus for memory, and cerebellar tonsil for executive function were also observed.
Conclusion: This article demonstrates that cerebrum, cerebellum (especially posterior lobe) and brainstem (red nucleus) all attribute to the improvement of mental health by exercise intervention via different pathways based on structural and functional evidences. Future diagnosis, treatment and rehabilitation of mental health illness should put the brain regions mentioned and their roles in network into full consideration, for it is what we usually neglect that may leave lasting impacts on patients’ daily living activities and quality of life.

q2.value: To first investigate the effects of exercise interventions on mental health through coordinate-based meta-analysis across neuroimaging studies, exploring relevant activated brain regions and interplay among them.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Meta-analysis

q8.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value:
Methods
This study will follow the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA) guidelines. 
Data sources 
The literature search will be conducted from an inception to March 2020, through four electronic databases (Pubmed, Web of Science, PsychInfo, and Embase).  Search terms in title and abstract will be combined as follow: (“psychological outcome” OR “mental health” OR “anxiety” OR “depression” OR “stress” OR “emotion” OR “mood” OR “affective” OR “social well-being” OR “behavioral outcome” OR “cognition” OR “memory” OR “executive function”) AND (“exercise” OR “sports” OR “physical activity” OR “physical training” OR “movement” OR “motor skill training”) AND (“fMRI” OR “functional MRI” OR “functional magnetic resonance imaging” OR “PET” OR “positron emission tomography”). Furthermore, reference lists of included articles will be manually searched for relevant articles that may not captured through the database searches. 
Inclusion criteria and study selection 
Studies will only be included if they meet the following inclusion criteria: (1) peer-review journal article published in English; (2) pre-to-post experimental design with at least one group that was arranged to attend an exercise program; (3) evaluation of task-related brain activity via fMRI or PET at baseline and post-intervention; (4) functional imaging task associated with mental health (e.g., depression, anxiety, fear, or cognition); (5) retrievable data on standard Talairach or Montreal Neurologic Institute (MNI) coordinates of whole-brain analyses, allowing for comparison of findings across studies and across laboratories. Two independent researchers (QY and LZ) will first screen article titles and abstracts, followed by full-text review against the above-mentioned inclusion criteria.

q11.value: After screening, a quantitative Activation Likelihood Estimation meta-analysis was performed in 15 studies (19 experiments, 189 foci) with 593 participants to evaluate the contrast pre- versus post- exercise effects on mental health.

question.value:
Data extraction 
For the included studies, data will be independently extracted by two reviewers (QY and LZ), including imaging mode, population (health status) and age, intervention of experimental group (exercise type and the number of participants), intervention duration, task/stimuli, control type, and the number of Foci.

Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE) 
ALE is a coordinate-based meta-analytical method that has been used to determine the consistent locations of brain activation in included studies that use similar experimental conditions or tasks. In ALE, activation foci are regarded as probability distributions centered on the reported coordinates. ALE maps are constructed after calculating each space voxel’s likelihood to be activated. The null-distributions acquired from independent studies’ ALE values is usually used to test the reliability of ALE map and this process have similarities with permutation test across experiments. The contribution of each study is weighted by its sample size, and each study is considered as a random effect. The observed values in the ALE distribution are compared to the null distribution in order to assign probability estimates to the observed experimental data.
In this study, we will perform ALE analyses with GingerALE v3.0.2 in Talairach space, and set the direct P-value threshold at 0.001 and a minimum cluster size at 100 mm3 [1-3]. Then GingerALE will perform cluster analysis on the thresholded map, based on the minimum volume that is specified in the previous step [1-3]. Coordinates reported in Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) space in the original studies will be transformed to the Talairach using the Lancaster transform icbm2tal software procedure included in the Convert Foci tool of GingerALE [4]. The ALE maps will be imported into Mango Version 4.1 software and overlaid on an anatomical template in Talairach space for representation and comparison [5].

registration_responses.q2: To first investigate the effects of exercise interventions on mental health through coordinate-based meta-analysis across neuroimaging studies, exploring relevant activated brain regions and interplay among them.
registration_responses.q3: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q8: Registration following analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: After screening, a quantitative Activation Likelihood Estimation meta-analysis was performed in 15 studies (19 experiments, 189 foci) with 593 participants to evaluate the contrast pre- versus post- exercise effects on mental health.
registration_responses.q6.question: Meta-analysis
registration_responses.q10.question:
Methods
This study will follow the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA) guidelines. 
Data sources 
The literature search will be conducted from an inception to March 2020, through four electronic databases (Pubmed, Web of Science, PsychInfo, and Embase).  Search terms in title and abstract will be combined as follow: (“psychological outcome” OR “mental health” OR “anxiety” OR “depression” OR “stress” OR “emotion” OR “mood” OR “affective” OR “social well-being” OR “behavioral outcome” OR “cognition” OR “memory” OR “executive function”) AND (“exercise” OR “sports” OR “physical activity” OR “physical training” OR “movement” OR “motor skill training”) AND (“fMRI” OR “functional MRI” OR “functional magnetic resonance imaging” OR “PET” OR “positron emission tomography”). Furthermore, reference lists of included articles will be manually searched for relevant articles that may not captured through the database searches. 
Inclusion criteria and study selection 
Studies will only be included if they meet the following inclusion criteria: (1) peer-review journal article published in English; (2) pre-to-post experimental design with at least one group that was arranged to attend an exercise program; (3) evaluation of task-related brain activity via fMRI or PET at baseline and post-intervention; (4) functional imaging task associated with mental health (e.g., depression, anxiety, fear, or cognition); (5) retrievable data on standard Talairach or Montreal Neurologic Institute (MNI) coordinates of whole-brain analyses, allowing for comparison of findings across studies and across laboratories. Two independent researchers (QY and LZ) will first screen article titles and abstracts, followed by full-text review against the above-mentioned inclusion criteria.

Data extraction 
For the included studies, data will be independently extracted by two reviewers (QY and LZ), including imaging mode, population (health status) and age, intervention of experimental group (exercise type and the number of participants), intervention duration, task/stimuli, control type, and the number of Foci.

Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE) 
ALE is a coordinate-based meta-analytical method that has been used to determine the consistent locations of brain activation in included studies that use similar experimental conditions or tasks. In ALE, activation foci are regarded as probability distributions centered on the reported coordinates. ALE maps are constructed after calculating each space voxel’s likelihood to be activated. The null-distributions acquired from independent studies’ ALE values is usually used to test the reliability of ALE map and this process have similarities with permutation test across experiments. The contribution of each study is weighted by its sample size, and each study is considered as a random effect. The observed values in the ALE distribution are compared to the null distribution in order to assign probability estimates to the observed experimental data.
In this study, we will perform ALE analyses with GingerALE v3.0.2 in Talairach space, and set the direct P-value threshold at 0.001 and a minimum cluster size at 100 mm3 [1-3]. Then GingerALE will perform cluster analysis on the thresholded map, based on the minimum volume that is specified in the previous step [1-3]. Coordinates reported in Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) space in the original studies will be transformed to the Talairach using the Lancaster transform icbm2tal software procedure included in the Convert Foci tool of GingerALE [4]. The ALE maps will be imported into Mango Version 4.1 software and overlaid on an anatomical template in Talairach space for representation and comparison [5].

q1.value: Maura Flynn, Clare Conry-Murray, Mackenzie Gillen, Thomas Joseph Harrison

q2.value:
It is predicted that there will be a main effect of age on drinking habits such that younger adults will be more likely to change drinking habits than full adults. 

In addition, there will be an interaction between age and condition such that younger adults in the low condition will be more likely to change their drinking habits in the future than older adults given a low statistical estimation.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
2x2 design 
 age group( young adults ages 18-22 and full adults 23 and older) x weekly drinking habits of Americans

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: posting a link to the survey on social media so participants can voluntarily and anonymously fill out the questions. The survey included demographics, a measure of age group, and 2 between subject conditions indicating that a lot of Americans drink 4 or more drinks a week or few Americans drink 4 or more drinks a week. Participants are assigned to each the condition based on their phone number.

q11.value:
Ideally there will be 20 per between subject group for a total of 80 participants. 
40 in the young adult group and 40 in the full adult group
Within each age population half should be in the low condition and half in the high condition 
Data collection is expected between 40 and 120 participants

q12.value: Dr. Conry- Mury told us we had to get 20 subjects per cell of between subjects.

q13.value: I plan to stop collecting data once I get 25 per cell.

question.value:
According to a study conducted by the Department of Psychology at Harvard University in 2019, 76% of Americans say they drink 4 or more drinks a week. In this study one drink is equal to one 12 oz. beer, 5 oz of wine, or 1.5 oz of distilled spirits. On a day when you are consuming alcohol, about how many drinks do you consume? 

According to a study conducted by the Department of Psychology at Harvard University in 2019, 14% of Americans say they drink 4 or more drinks a week. In this study one drink is equal to one 12 oz. beer, 5 oz of wine, or 1.5 oz of distilled spirits. On a day when you are consuming alcohol, about how many drinks do you consume?

IV: age group as a subject variable
DV: change in alcohol behavior operationalized as current drinks per week total - future expected drinks per week total
change in alcohol behavior operationalized as current drinks per week total - future expected drinks per week total
ANOVA to test for interaction between age and change in alcohol behavior

attributes.title: Ryenn Hayes's Final Project
attributes.description: Final Project for Dr. Conry-Murray's Research Methods class 2020

q1.value: Ryenn Hayes, Clare Conry-Murray, Mackenzie Gillen, Thomas Joseph Harrison

q2.value: I hypothesize that there will be a main effect of age on outlook where those below the age of thirty will have an overall lower outlook than those aged thirty and above. Additionally, there will be a main effect of the type of news received on outlook where those receiving the negative news will have a lower outlook than those receiving the positive news. Lastly, there will be an interaction between the type of news received and age where those below the age of thirty who view the negative news will have a lower outlook than those aged thirty and above who also view the negative news.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: 2(age:below 30 vs. 30+) x2(news:positive vs. negative) between subjects design.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: I posted a link to social media in order to account for the population under the age of thirty. I then had my mother post the link to social media as well to account for the population aged thirty and above. The survey covers demographics, a measure of one's outlook on the future, and two conditions displaying either positive or negative news. Participants are randomly assigned into the conditions based on the last digit of their phone number.

q11.value: Ideally, I will have a total of around 80 participants. That way there is on average at least 20 participants per the four between subjects groups. I expect to have around 70-90 participants.

q12.value: My professor said to collect data from 20 people per between subject group.

q13.value: I plan to stop collecting data if I reach 100 participants.

question.value:
News- 2 levels
1. Negative: On Tuesday, city health officials said at least 1,315 people had tested positive for the corona virus in Philadelphia.

Fourteen people have died of the virus in the city.

Among the people infected are dozens of health care workers, at least one Department of Corrections employee and one inmate of a city jail, though officials would not say which jail.

At least five of the city's deaths have happened among patients at nursing homes, city Health Commissioner Dr. Thomas Farley said.

And, he said, the virus has been reported in every Philadelphia zip code. "It's entirely clear that this virus is everywhere in the city," Farley said Monday.

As of March 31st there have been 4,843 cases and 63 deaths in the entire state of Pennsylvania.
2. Positive: Most people with COVID-19 recover. Estimates now suggest that 99% of people infected with the virus that causes COVID-19 will recover. Some people have no symptoms at all. And while thousands of people have died, the overall death rate is about 1% (or perhaps even lower), far less than MERS (about 34%), SARS (about 11%), or Ebola (90%)

IV: Age-- <30 and 30+
DV: How positive is your outlook on the future?

I have a new measure from a scale of strongly disagree(1) to strongly agree(6) where a participant's answers will be averaged to get a score describing their outlook on the future with 1 being negative to 6 being positive.

I will be calculating reliability on my new measure as well as an ANOVA to test for an interaction between age and outlook, an ANOVA to test for a main effect of age on outlook, and an ANOVA to test for a main effect of type of news on outlook.

registration_responses.q2: I hypothesize that there will be a main effect of age on outlook where those below the age of thirty will have an overall lower outlook than those aged thirty and above. Additionally, there will be a main effect of the type of news received on outlook where those receiving the negative news will have a lower outlook than those receiving the positive news. Lastly, there will be an interaction between the type of news received and age where those below the age of thirty who view the negative news will have a lower outlook than those aged thirty and above who also view the negative news.

attributes.title: Fluid Resuscitation in Surgical Patients: A Systematic Review and Network Meta-analysis
attributes.description: Fluid therapy is one of an irreplaceable medical therapeutic interventions in surgical patients. There is a debate over whether colloids or crystalloids are better for fluid resuscitation.

q2.value: Crystalloid solutions lead to decreased mortality compared with colloid solutions.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The present analysis is a network meta-analysis. 
Eligible studies meet the following PICOS (participants, interventions, comparators, outcomes, and study design) criteria will be included: 
(1) Population: The population of interest included adults (age≥18) undergoing surgery. 
(2) Intervention: four types of colloid fluids, divided into albumin, gelatin, dextran, and HES. (3) Comparison: crystalloid fluid.
(4) Outcome: The primary outcome is all-cause mortality at 90-day follow-up or, if not available, 30-day, intensive care unit, or hospital mortality, whichever was longest. Secondary outcomes were renal replacement therapy, and length of stay in hospital. 
(5) Study design: prospective and randomized trials. 
Besides, we will exclude (1) trials with more than 25% patients that undergoing cardiac; (2) trials that compared different types of crystalloid fluid.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Several databases including Ovid MEDLINE, Ovid EMBASE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials will be searched from inception to March 18, 2020 irrespective of language. We will also perform a recursive search of the bibliographies of these selected articles as well as published systematic reviews on this topic, to identify any additional studies. 
Four reviewers working in 2 pairs will screen the titles and abstracts to determine potential eligibility, and entries identified by any reviewer proceeded to the full-text eligibility review. Conflicts in study selection will be resolved by consensus, or determined by another independent reviewer.

q11.value: We will include as many studies and as many patients as possible.

question.value: The primary outcome is all-cause mortality at 90-day follow-up or, if not available, 30-day, intensive care unit, or hospital mortality, whichever was longest. Secondary outcomes are renal replacement therapy (RRT), and length of stay (LOS) in hospital.

The primary analyses are a 5-node NMA (crystalloids vs. albumin vs. HES vs. gelatin vs. dextran). We will conduct Bayesian network meta-analyses using a consistency model in the R environment by using gemtc package.  The models are based on 20,000 iterations with a burn-in of 8,000 iterations. Risk ratio (RR) and the corresponding 95% credible interval (CrI) will be obtained using the 2.5th and 97.5th percentiles of the posterior distribution. The rankograms are estimated to rank the intervention hierarchy in the network meta-analysis. Heterogeneity of treatment effects among included studies will be examined using the Cochrane Q test and I2 statistic. We will check for publication bias using Egger’s regression asymmetry test and a two-sided p value of <0.05 are regarded as significant. 
Sensitivity analyses will be conducted for the primary outcome by excluding studies that at overall high risk of bias, that were published before 2000, that with one or more treatment arms of <20 patients.
Risk of bias for all RCTs will be assessed using the Cochrane Collaboration Risk of Bias tool across seven domains: random sequence generation; allocation concealment; blinding of study participants, blinding of outcome assessment, incomplete outcome data, selective reporting and other potential sources of bias. Each domain is assessed as either low, unclear or high risk of bias. We will contact the original study investigators for more information if necessary.
All analyses will be done in R (release version 3.6.3) and RevMan (5.3.3; The Cochrane Collaboration).

registration_responses.q2: Crystalloid solutions lead to decreased mortality compared with colloid solutions.
registration_responses.q3: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
